text: The hearth crackles softly, and the scent of warmed wine lingers in the air.
“I’ll probably just keep living as usual,” I say absentmindedly. “Running the inn, fixing doors, dealing with drunkards. Life has to go on.”
She looks at me, her expression complicated—half thoughtful, half scrutinizing.
“Avoidance isn’t peace,” she says softly. The tone is light, yet it pierces the air like a fine needle.
She taps the rim of her glass with her fingertip, producing a faint sound that seems unusually clear in the quiet inn.
“Sometimes people think they’re living,” she says, gazing into the firelight, her voice calm, “when in truth they’re just being pushed along by time.”
“Maybe being pushed along is easier,” I reply quietly.
“Then let it be so.” She smiles faintly and withdraws her gaze. The smile is gentle, yet separated by a distance that cannot be crossed.
In that moment, I suddenly feel that she isn’t speaking to me at all—but recalling something, a past long beyond redemption.
Firelight washes over her profile, light and shadow intertwining like a dream no one can pass through.
